questions.question: According to the '7-Eyed Model' of supervision discussed in Lesson 2, which 'eye' focuses on the 'Parallel Process'—where the supervisee unintentionally recreates the client's dynamics within the supervision session?
options: Eye 1: The Client's Context
Eye 3: The Therapist-Client Relationship
Eye 5: The Supervisor-Supervisee Relationship
Eye 7: The Wider Context
questions.explanation: Eye 5 focuses on the relationship between the supervisor and supervisee, which is where the parallel process typically manifests, reflecting the dynamics of the therapist-client relationship.

questions.question: In the context of EFT, how is 'Countertransference' most commonly identified by a therapist during a tapping session?
options: The therapist forgets the setup phrase
The therapist feels an intense emotional reaction or physical sensation that mirrors or reacts to the client's narrative
The client refuses to tap on a specific acupoint
The therapist suggests a cognitive reframing too early in the process
questions.explanation: Countertransference in EFT often manifests as 'somatic resonance' or emotional triggers where the therapist's own unresolved issues or reactions to the client interfere with the neutral 'holding space'.

questions.question: When mentoring using the T.A.P.P.I.N.G. Method™, what does the 'P' for 'Pinpoint' specifically require the mentee to demonstrate?
options: The ability to pick a random acupoint
The ability to identify the specific sensory 'snapshot' or micro-moment of a traumatic memory
The ability to persuade the client to change their mind
The ability to predict the client's next emotional shift
questions.explanation: In the T.A.P.P.I.N.G. Method™, Pinpointing refers to the clinical skill of finding the specific, narrow aspect of a memory that carries the highest emotional charge.

questions.question: Lesson 5 highlights that approximately what percentage of trauma-informed practitioners experience 'Vicarious Trauma' or 'Compassion Fatigue' at some point in their career, necessitating ethical oversight?
options: Less than 10%
Between 15% and 25%
Between 40% and 85%
Exactly 100%
questions.explanation: Research indicates high rates (40-85%) of secondary traumatic stress among helping professionals, making regular supervision an ethical requirement for practitioner longevity.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between 'Administrative Supervision' and 'Clinical Supervision' as defined in Lesson 1?
options: Administrative focuses on the therapist's personal life; Clinical focuses on the client
Administrative focuses on organizational policy and caseload; Clinical focuses on therapeutic skill and client outcomes
There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable
Clinical supervision is only for beginners; Administrative is for experts
questions.explanation: Administrative supervision ensures compliance with agency or business rules, while clinical supervision focuses on the quality of the therapeutic intervention and the practitioner's professional growth.

questions.question: In Peer Supervision groups (Lesson 6), what is the 'Stewardship' model of facilitation?
options: One person is the permanent boss of the group
A rotating responsibility where members take turns managing the group's time, safety, and focus
A model where only the most senior therapist provides feedback
A model where no one is allowed to give feedback
questions.explanation: The stewardship model in peer groups promotes equality and shared responsibility by rotating the facilitator role among members.

questions.question: Which feedback mechanism is considered 'Formative' in the T.A.P.P.I.N.G. Method™ competency assessment?
options: A final exam at the end of the year
Ongoing, developmental feedback provided during the learning process to improve performance
A 'Pass/Fail' grade on a certification video
A client's satisfaction survey after 10 sessions
questions.explanation: Formative assessment is 'for' learning—it is the continuous feedback loop that helps a mentee adjust their technique in real-time.

questions.question: A supervisee reports feeling 'stuck' with a client who is highly dissociative. If the supervisor notices they are also feeling 'stuck' or distant during the supervision session, this is a classic example of:
options: Incompetence
Parallel Process
The Apex Effect
Cognitive Dissonance
questions.explanation: Parallel process occurs when the supervisee unconsciously enacts the client's patterns (dissociation/stuckness) within the relationship with the supervisor.

questions.question: Under Ethical Oversight (Lesson 5), what is the 'Gold Standard' for managing a dual relationship in a small community?
options: Ignoring the relationship and hoping for the best
Full disclosure, written informed consent, and ongoing supervision to monitor boundaries
Immediately terminating the client relationship without explanation
Charging the client double to ensure professional distance
questions.explanation: Ethical risk management for dual relationships requires transparency, documented consent, and external supervision to ensure the client's interests remain primary.

questions.question: To build a 'Sustainable Mentorship Practice' (Lesson 8), a mentor should prioritize which of the following to prevent 'Mentor Burnout'?
options: Taking on as many mentees as possible to increase revenue
Setting clear 'Office Hours' and maintaining their own clinical supervision
Only mentoring friends and family
Avoiding any feedback that might upset the mentee
questions.explanation: Sustainability is built on clear boundaries (office hours) and the mentor's own support system (supervision-of-supervision) to manage the emotional load of the role.
